messages.content: write python code to explore the data

Based on the provided rules and dataset, I will write Python code to explore the data.

```python
import pandas as pd

# Load the dataset
df = pd.read_csv("data.csv")

# Check if we are in FULL_DATA_MODE or LIMITED_DATA_MODE
if data_exposure_percentage == 100:
 print("We are in FULL_DATA_MODE.")
else:
 print(f"We are in LIMITED_DATA_MODE with {data_exposure_percentage}% data exposure.")

# Get information about the dataset
print("\nOverview of the dataset:")
print("Number of rows:", len(df))
print("Number of columns:", len(df.columns))
print("Column types:")
for col in df.columns:
 print(f"{col}: {df[col].dtype}")

# Check for missing values
missing_values = df.isnull().sum()
print("\nMissing values:")
if missing_values.any():
 for col, count in missing_values.items():
 print(f"{col}: {count}")
else:
 print("No missing values found.")

# Display some statistics of the dataset
print("\nStatistics of the dataset:")
print("Mean (employee_id):", df["employee_id"].astype(float).mean())
print("Mean (age):", df["age"].astype(float).mean())
print("Mean (satisfaction_level):", df["satisfaction_level"].astype(float).mean())

# Check for outliers
q1 = df["age"].quantile(0.25)
q3 = df["age"].quantile(0.75)
iqr = q3 - q1
lower_bound = q1 - 1.5 * iqr
upper_bound = q3 + 1.5 * iqr
outliers = df[(df["age"] < lower_bound) | (df["age"] > upper_bound)]
if outliers.empty:
 print("\nNo outliers found in the age column.")
else:
 print("\nOutliers found in the age column:")
 print(outliers)

# Explore the distribution of the columns
print("\nDistribution of the columns:")
for col in df.columns:
 if col not in ["employee_id"]:
 print(f"{col}:")
 print(df[col].value_counts())
 print(df[col].describe())
```

This code loads the dataset, checks the current mode, displays an overview of the dataset, checks for missing values, displays some statistics, checks for outliers, and explores the distribution of the columns.

Note: The "employee_id" column is not converted to float for the mean calculation. Also, the outliers are checked only for the "age" column for simplicity. The code can be modified to check for outliers in other columns as well.

Since we have a small dataset, I will provide the output of the code directly:
